review.title: “Arthur D. Little Review”
review.pros: Pros – Good work/life Balance. Average hours is not as crazy as other consulting firms.Friendly co-workers. Very open culture. Managers, Sr. Managers and Directors are accessible at all times.
review.cons: Cons – Low salary. No salary revisions for the last two years. No bonus for 2009. Average salary lower than average in the industry.Low opportunity for career advancement. The firm is stuck with no growth potential
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Change of senior management is needed.

review.title: “Internationally respected company with opportunities for professional growth but limited in career advancement”
review.pros: Pros – ADL is an internationally respected brand name with a wide network of expert advisors. It has a fun, collegiate culture, with a strong entrepreneurial streak due to its small office nature. It has offices all over the world, giving consultants the opportunity for international travel and working with diverse clients.
review.cons: Cons – The company is often very hierarchal, with sometimes very poor communication between management and junior levels. The problem may be rooted in the fact that most of its locations have a very small office feel yet are a part of a larger corporate network, leading to somewhat autonomous, even rebellious, nature. Adding to the tension and suspicion is the fact that ADL is owned by public company Altran.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Needs to be more of a meritocracy and a focus on delivering results (ie, selling projects)

review.title: “Still a good name, but...”

review.cons: Cons – Work culture not the best. Financing dept a pain with expenses. Lack of social activities. Generally suffering from a lack of new blood at the higher levels.

review.title: “Review: Internship at Arthur D. Little”
review.pros: Pros – still a strong brand among industry pundits, highly professional, more senior than other consulting firms
review.cons: Cons – ADL serve considerably smaller clients than MBB, the have less structured processes (which, however, allows for more creative freedom in the daily work as a consultant)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – processes need to be streamlined in order to regain forces, maybe a merger with a strong partner would help ADL to come back to former glory

review.title: “US operations are floundering, and unless new directors with sales skills join fast, it may be a sinking ship.”
review.pros: Pros – Opportunity to work on an interesting range of projects, some with a strategic scope. Many projects involve limited travel to the client site, improving work/life balance. Reputation as a collegial firm is generally justified.
review.cons: Cons – No understandable connection between effort and bonus calculation. Several good directors have left the firm in recent months. The few directors left can't generate enough revenue to support all the staff. With the corporate parent reluctant to invest further, the future for the US offices appears bleak.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Either invest further in the US operations (adding directors who can sell and staff), or consider either selling the US operations to another firm or disband the US effort entirely.

review.title: “Great Brand but for How Long?”
review.pros: Pros – Interesting projects to work with diverse clients and skillsets. Great brand recognition in the marketplace. Great peer group to team with on assignments.
review.cons: Cons – Lack of coherent management strategy; lots of turnover just as progress to re-establish US business is taking off. Uncertainty as to survivability of the US business.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Create a strategy and stick with the people chosen to lead. Fund the growth through the lean economic times. Create less Europe dominant group.

review.cons: Cons – Low compensation and employee benefits.Employee compensation is much below industry benchmarks. To add to the dis-satisfaction, middle east is not hospitable either with its extreme weather, high cost, and limited social activities.Hence compensation is one of the prime motivators for a professional working in this region

review.title: “An Intern's Peek”
